issues.title: URI Format
issues.author: jsalowey
issues.body: the definition seems to be a little bit different than what is in the architecture spec.  For example, its not clear to me that the urn format is compatible: urn:example:container:db-read-replica.  This URN does not have a trust domain.  I think this will cause problems when defining how to use an identity.  IF the trust domain is not included then how does the consumer know what the trust domain is?

issues.title: Usage in Credentials
issues.author: jsalowey
issues.body: The format of the credentials is discussed in the s2s spec.  My initial thoughts are that the definition of how the identifier fits in a credential should remain there as it talks about how the identifier is used in that credential.

issues.title: Path Portion of URI
issues.author: jsalowey
issues.body: It might be worth saying that the path portion of the URI is not specified in this document and is outside the scope of this specification.  Without specific deployment knowledge the consumer of the identity can only identify the trust domain.

issues.title: Scope and uniquness
issues.author: jsalowey
issues.body: What a workload is is somewhat ambiguous.  For example a workload could refer just to the software that is being run (Auto-parts-orderer) or it can refer to software being run in some environment (Auto-Parts-sorter/us-arizona) or it can even refer to a specific instance of running code (/23a5s7sd-efjf39400f-wefjj49).  All of these scopes within which they are unique.

issues.title: Should we support schema-specific trust domains?
issues.author: yaroslavros
issues.body: For example in case of [ARN](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/reference-arns.html) "trust domain" would be `partition:service:region:account-id`. However it would be easy to convert it to something more sane such as `account-id.region.service.partition`.

issues.title: Maximum URI length
issues.author: yaroslavros
issues.body: SPIFFE limits maximum ID length to 2048. Should we introduce a similar limitation?

issues.title: Non-ascii characters and percent encoding
issues.author: yaroslavros
issues.body: To reduce security risks of mis-parsing URIs SPIFFE prohibits usage of non-ascii characters and percent encoding in IDs. Should we do the same here?

issues.title: Align terminology
issues.author: yaroslavros
issues.body: This document defines a number of terms that are vary slightly from definitions in other specifications. We need to align this.

issues.title: Uniqueness
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: The document (possibly in Sec. 4.4) should be more explicit about what the identifier denotes. For example, if I have a service running in 2 regions with 4 instances in each one, would I have 1 identifier for all of them (I think yes).

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body:
One more on uniqueness. This paragraph is simply incorrect:
> Workload Identifiers are globally unique when the trust domain is globally unique. This is typically achieved by using a fully qualified domain name (FQDN) under organisational control.

An FQDN is used only for trust domains, if the whole Identifier is to be unique, the path portion needs to be managed for uniqueness by the organization.

Also, I'm not quite sure the IETF does UK English spelling...

issues.title: Scope outside WIMSE?
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: "This specification is intended to be generic and reusable beyond the context of any single system or architecture, including but not limited to the Workload Identity in Multi-System Environments (WIMSE) architecture [[ARCH](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rosomakho-wimse-identifier-00.html#ARCH)]" - I think it's better to focus on WIMSE.

issues.title: Mapping from an external handle
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: We have been debating in S2S how these identifiers can be validated, resulting in [a new section](https://ietf-wg-wimse.github.io/draft-ietf-wimse-s2s-protocol/draft-ietf-wimse-s2s-protocol.html#name-workload-identifiers-and-au). Do we want to extend the current document to describe how external handles (the hostname+path used to call into a service) can be mapped into WL identifiers? This seems to be critical in practice.

issues.title: URI Scheme
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: This is an ongoing discussion, and IMO someone needs to make the jump and define a "wimse" scheme. Why not here? See also [this issue](https://github.com/ietf-wg-wimse/draft-ietf-wimse-s2s-protocol/issues/123).

comments.author: yaroslavros
comments.body:
Perhaps a good topic for upcoming interim!

@jsalowey , what do you think?

comments.author: yaronf
comments.body: In the meantime we defined it in S2S, and the WG seems to be happy with it (IIRC we brought it up in Madrid). Still possible to move it to this document once it gets adopted.

issues.title: Scheme specific portion - versions?
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: Does it ever make sense for the WL identifier to refer to a specific version? That  would make it nearly unusable for defining authorization policies.

comments.author: yaroslavros
comments.body:
I don't think workload identifier schemes should have generic versions in them. This feels messy. Also I don't see any examples of that in https://www.iana.org/assignments/uri-schemes/uri-schemes.xhtml 


If one is redefining their path hierarchy they could add version information inside the path which is quite common in REST API.

issues.title: Usage in credentials and tokens
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: Arguably this is out of scope for this document, and should be defined by the relevant protocols.

issues.title: JSON Web Tokens
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: The identifier is also usable in the `aud` claim. Also we might end up using [Subject Identifiers](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/rfc9493/). Again, this whole usage section IMO should not belong in this document.

issues.title: Which SPIFFE requirements should we take?
issues.author: yaroslavros
issues.body:
[SPIFFE-ID](https://github.com/spiffe/spiffe/blob/main/standards/SPIFFE-ID.md) has the following restrictions:

- host MUST NOT be empty
- userinfo and port MUST be empty
- host MUST be lowercase
- host MUST contain only [a-z0-9.-_], path may contain uppercase A-Z on top of that
- host and path MUST not contain percent-encoded characters
- path MUST NOT include trailing /
- path MUST not include relative modifiers
- URI length up to 2048 MUST be supported and SHOULD not exceed that limit

Obviously, we are not going to relax SPIFFE specific requirements, but we don't have to inherit exact same limitations which could be too limiting for other schemes. For example, allowing IPv4 addresses in host portion, but not IPv6 seems wrong.

I would propose to:

- let schemes define their own path restriction
- inherit URI length requirement and recommendation
- add host MUST NOT be empty and userinfo and port MUST be empty
- relax requirements to host compared to SPIFFE - allow any valid non-empty hostname

And add security considerations about percent-encoding and equivalency matching of URIs.

@jsalowey what do you think? Should we bring this up at the architecture interim?
